Subjective visual vertical in virtual reality (Curator SVV): validation and normative data
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 20 February 2018

Subjective visual vertical in virtual reality (Curator SVV): validation and normative data

  • Elodie Chiarovano1,
  • Leigh A. McGarvie1,2,
  • David Szmulewicz3 &
  • Hamish G. MacDougall1 

Virtual Reality volume 22, pages315–320(2018)Cite this article

  • 455 Accesses

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Subjective visual vertical (SVV) assesses the ability to perceive verticality, which is a measure of vestibular otolithic function. Vestibular lesions influence this perception of verticality. We developed a method using virtual reality (VR) display and an Android software application named ‘Curator SVV’. The virtual reality SVV (Curator SVV) consisted of ten readily identifiable artworks projected by a Samsung phone S6 which is inserted into a virtual reality headset. In the first study, 20 patients had there SVV assessed with two devices: (1) a commercially available SVV measurement device (VestiTest®) and (2) a virtual reality SVV using the Curator SVV application. In a second study, 32 healthy subjects had their SVV assessed by the Curator SVV application whilst sitting in a chair. In the first study, there was no significant difference (p = 0.44, paired t test and p = 0.01, test of equivalence) between results obtained by Curator SVV and the commercially available device. In the second study, the average angle measured for healthy subjects was 0.00° ± 0.85°. The normal range (mean ± 2 SD) was ± 2° in standard upright position. We were able to demonstrate that the Curator SVV can be readily employed as an objective, non-invasive and affordable means of assessing otolith function in the clinical context. We validated this novel methodology by finding strong quantitative parity between a standard commercial SVV unit and the VR Curator SVV method. Our very lightweight and mobile device can be employed in clinical contexts including at the bedside and in different head and body positions.

Introduction

Subjective visual vertical (SVV) is a test which assesses the ability to perceive verticality—a vestibular otolithic function (Sun et al. 2014). The judgment of verticality is altered when there is a vestibular otolith dysfunction (Curthoys et al. 1991b). Vestibular lesions influence gravitational verticality perception via ocular torsional effects (Curthoys et al. 1991a) which are reflected by a visual bias in the standard upright position (Curthoys et al. 1991a). The purpose of SVV is to measure visual bias in order to detect abnormal subjective tilt of the perceive verticality. There is a close relationship between torsional eye position measurements and abnormal tilt of the verticality results in patients with vestibular otolith dysfunction (Bronstein et al. 2003). Healthy subjects are able to align an illuminated bar of LED with the vertical (earth gravity vector) within ± 2° of accuracy in darkness, but following vestibular schwannoma (VS) surgery or an acute unilateral peripheral vestibulopathy, there is a tilt (visual bias) of the perceive verticality towards the lesioned side (Hafström et al. 2004). With time and central brain compensation process, tilt returns to normal limits (Batuecas-Caletrio et al. 2013; Ogawa et al. 2010).

SVV is often performed with the subject seated with head fixed and in total darkness, using a series of projected LEDs. The test conditions are rather arduous and additionally, require significant space and time. Another version of assessing the SVV involves a bucket (Ferreira et al. 2016; Zwergal et al. 2009): a fluorescent bar is placed at the bottom of the bucket and patients rotate the bucket to align the bar with their perception of verticality. The clinician then reads the angle at the bottom of the bucket. However, the accuracy is limited to approximately one degree (Zwergal et al. 2009) and this may introduce significant imprecision.

Here, we developed a novel method of measuring vestibular otolith function by employing virtual reality (VR) display and a purpose designed Android software application: Curator SVV. Our aims were:

  1. 1.

    To demonstrate that this approach could be performed on patients

  2. 2.

    To validate Curator SVV by comparing the results obtained on the same patients with commercial standard SVV measurement device

  3. 3.

    To provide normative data for Curator SVV.

Methods

All subjects included in the study gave informed consent. The study was in accordance with the ethical standards of the Helsinki Declaration and was approved by the University of Sydney’s Human Research Ethics Committee—Protocol Number 2013/288.

In the first study (validation), 20 patients (10 F/10 M, mean age: 49 ± 17 years, range 14–83 years) had their SVV measured with two devices: (1) a commercially available SVV device and (2) the Curator SVV application with a virtual reality device. Patients were seated in total darkness on a chair with head fixed whilst being assessed with both devices.

The commercial SVV device (VestiTest®), consisted of a 120-mm bar with 20 red strips (5 mm each and separated by a 1 mm gap) (Fig. 1a). Subjects had to tilt the bar with a hand controller until they visually perceived the bar as a horizontal line. Ten trials were undertaken with a starting angle of: 10°; − 7°; − 12°; 10°; − 12°; 12°; − 10°; 12°; − 10° and 7° relative to the horizontal.

The virtual reality Curator SVV consisted of images of 10 easily identified oil paintings which were projected by a Samsung phone S6 inserted into a virtual reality headset (Gear VR, Fig. 1b). The equipment used was: a Samsung S6 (SM-G920); a Gear VR headset (Samsung Gear VR Second Innovator Edition SM-R321); and a Bluetooth remote controller (VR Box). The Gear VR with a Samsung S6 features a 577 pixel-per-inch display at 30 frames per seconds. The artworks were randomly presented on a black background with the same start angles as the VestiTest®. Subjects using a wireless hand-held controller had to tilt the images of the paintings until they were aligned with the subject’s perceived horizontal. The images of the 10 paintings were as follows: Mona Lisa (L. da Vinci), The flagellation of Christ (W. Bouguereau), Abundant harvest (T. Kinkade), The horse fair (R. Bonheur), Impression sunrise (C. Monet), Madonna and child (D. di Buoninsegna), Girl with a pearl earring (J. Vermeer), Self-portrait (V. Van Gogh), The kiss (G. Klimt) and Still life of fruit (unknown).

Patients included in this study were consecutively recorded without any inclusion or exclusion criteria. In practice, when a clinician required a SVV testing for a patient, the patient had been asked consent to perform Curator SVV as well as the classic SVV. Characteristics and diagnosis of patients are presented in Table 1. These patients were recorded at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital (RPA, Sydney, Australia) where they had been diagnosed with vestibular neuritis, acoustic schwannoma (before or after surgery), cochlear implant (after surgery), or hearing impairment (hearing loss or tinnitus). The ‘acute’ phase was defined as being less than 5 days after the onset of vestibular neuritis or surgical excision of an acoustic schwannoma. The ‘compensated’ phase was defined as being 5 days or more after the onset of vestibular neuritis or surgical excision of an acoustic schwannoma. In this first validation study, we included patients without and with (at different stages) vestibular disorders because of the purpose of the ‘validation’ study. Our aim was to evaluate if the VR Curator SVV was as accurate as the commercial SVV to detect a visual bias over a full range of responses.

In a second study, 32 healthy subjects (21F/11 M, mean age: 49 ± 21 years, range 18–87 years) had their SVV assessed with the Curator SVV whilst seated in a chair. Their head was not fixed. Healthy subjects were recruited by two separate ways: 14 subjects (44%) were recruited from University of Sydney and the Royal Victorian Eye and Ear Hospital staff members. The remaining subjects (n = 18, 56%) were selected out of a cohort of 125 patients consecutively recorded in a physiotherapist’s practice between June and October 2016. The former cohort of patients completed a battery of vestibular tests, including the video head impulse test (vHIT) of all six semicircular canals (MacDougall et al. 2013), cervical and ocular vestibular evoked myogenic potentials (VEMPs) in response to Hammer taps at the Fz position (Curthoys et al. 2011), and a standing balance test using a foam pad (Airex® Balance Pad blue) (Chiarovano et al. 2017). Inclusion in the healthy subject’s group required: (1) no more complain or symptoms of vertigo, dizziness, or disorientation and (2) normal vestibular function (normal semicircular canal function as assessed by the vHIT, normal otolithic function assessed by VEMPs testing and the ability to maintain their balance for 20 s whilst standing on the Airex® Balance Pad blue with eyes closed). Subjects included in the healthy group were fully recovered neuritis, BPPV after treatment, or cervicogenic dizziness after treatment. Subjects suffering from diplopia were exclude from the analyse.

In study 1, the average of the response’s angles of the 10 trials gathered by each of the two devices were calculated and compared with a paired t test and a test of equivalence (SAS 9.4 statistical software) and a Bland and Altman graph. In study 2, normative range was calculated by mean ± 2 SD. Base on the small variability of the normative data found in the literature, a sample size of 30 healthy subjects was evaluated. For both studies, if the response angle was equal to the start angle, the response angle was deleted from the analysis.

Results

Study 1 (validation): the means of the response angles gathered with Curator SVV was compared with the means of the response angles gathered with the VestiTest® for all patients (Fig. 2a). The mean of the difference (VestiTest®—Curator) is − 0.09° ± 1.84° (min; max: − 2.11°; 6.43°). This mean was not significantly different from zero (p = 0.44, paired t test) which indicated no significant difference between Curator and VestiTest® results. The test of equivalence was significant (p = 0.01) within 1° of difference which indicated an equivalence between both measures. However, one patient results (0.05%) showed a difference between the two devices with a mean response’s angle of 4.62° with the VestiTest® and − 1.81° with the Curator, as shown on the Bland and Altman plot (red cross in Fig. 2b).

Study 2 (normative data): the distribution of responses using the Curator SVV on healthy subjects is displayed in Fig. 3. The average (± SD) of the response angles for the 32 healthy subjects was 0.00 ± 0.85° (min; max: − 1.71°; 1.63°). The normal range was between − 1.7 and +1.7° (mean ± 2SD). The head position during the test was recorded by the Gear VR headset. For all subjects, the angle of the head on the three axes (roll, pitch, yaw) was between − 3.46° and 4.97°.

Discussion

In this study, we were able to demonstrate that the newly developed VR Curator application for measuring SVV can be easily employed in the clinical assessment of dizzy patients. The device consists of readily obtainable and inexpensive equipment (a Gear VR headset, a Samsung S6 smartphone and a hand-held remote-control unit). A dark environment is not required as this is supplied by the VR headset. The precision of the angular measurements corresponds to the precision of the gyrometer in the VR headset (0.01°). Hence, the ease of the testing conditions and the improved accuracy are superior to existing devices. A previous study employed a smartphone to project a red line onto base of a bucket (in total darkness) (Brodsky et al. 2015). The authors noted that patients (children in this study) were particularly enthusiastic and compliant with the smartphone test, but that total darkness was still required. We employed images of very well-known oil paintings (and not projected dots or a line of LED) to improve subject engagement and to increase compliance by being able to simplify instructions (i.e. adjust the painting as you would do on a wall).

In healthy subjects assuming the upright position, the normative range of response angles was between +2° and − 2°. This is concordant with previous studies using a classical SVV measurement paradigm where the range of normality was identical (Dai et al. 1989; Tesio et al. 2011). Patients with acute unilateral vestibular dysfunction misperceive the direction of gravity and the SVV shifts towards the abnormal side (Bergenius et al. 1996; Curthoys et al. 1991b; Lopez et al. 2008). This phenomenon was measured by the VR Curator SVV in our cohort of acute stage vestibular dysfunction patients. Further investigations in clinical practice including more acute unilateral pathologies are required to validate these results. One patient returned results were discordant between the two devices. This patient was in the very early acute stage of vestibular neuritis. This patient was the only subject in our cohort who displayed spontaneous nystagmus (eye’s movement), and this may be the explanation for the discordant results. Further study on acute patients with spontaneous nystagmus is required in order to validate this hypothesis. Another hypothesis is that our VR Curator SVV is a composite of subjective visual vertical and horizontal. Indeed, artworks presented were square or rectangular and so included both horizontal and vertical components.

Finally, the new device is portable, so the test could be carried out at the bedside and in different head and body positions. The clinician can at any time control the head position of the subject, which is not possible with the other methods (i.e. in a dark room or with the patient’s head in a bucket). Additionally, the clinician can check the patient’s head position as the VR headset measures and records the head angle in all three planes (tilt, roll and pitch). This allows clinicians to make measures with different static otolithic inputs, for example, supine position results in a reduction of the otolithic influence. Previous studies used the supine position to assess the SVV, but with visual stimulus projected onto a vertical wall with the subject’s head slightly pitched forward (Lopez et al. 2008; Luyat et al. 1997; Saj et al. 2005). In this condition, the direction of the body axis and the direction of gravito-inertial force were dissociated and so, the perception of upright can be impaired when the body axis or the ‘idiotropic vector’ cannot be used to assess the direction of gravity (Mittelstaedt 1999). Therefore, the SVV is affected by the body position (Fernandez et al. 1972). With our novel method, we can assess the SVV in supine the position with the head completely horizontal and the images projected into the VR headset (as if onto the ‘ceiling’) that is parallel to the plane of the head.

In conclusion, we developed a mobile and portable means of the accurately assessing SVV using virtual reality and the Curator SVV application. We validated this against a commercially available and traditional means of SVV assessment and found a high degree of concordance. The range of normal measurements in healthy subjects was ± 2° (when tested in the upright position) and this concurs with the standards found in the literature (Dai et al. 1989). Curator SVV is available for free in the Oculus Store, more information can be found at http://www.psych.usyd.edu.au/humanfactors/mobile-apps/svv/.
